title: Cristina Díaz
text:
María Cristina Díaz Salazar is a Mexican lawyer and politician affiliated with the <a href="Institutional%20Revolutionary%20Party">Institutional Revolutionary Party</a> (PRI). She is a former <a href="municipal%20president">municipal president</a> (mayor) of <a href="Guadalupe%2C%20Nuevo%20Le%C3%B3n%20%28municipality%29">Guadalupe</a>, <a href="Nuevo%20Le%C3%B3n">Nuevo León</a>. Today, she is senator for the state of Nuevo León.
Education and professional career.
Díaz Salazar studied <a href="law">law</a> at the <a href="Universidad%20Aut%C3%B3noma%20de%20Nuevo%20Le%C3%B3n">Universidad Autónoma de Nuevo León</a> (UANL). She is an active member of the PRI who has occupied various positions inside her party including president of the PRI in Nuevo León. She has served as advisor for the <a href="National%20Social%20Security%20Workers%20Union">IMSS</a>, head of the <a href="National%20Institute%20of%20Migration">National Institute of Migration</a> in Nuevo León, local deputy in the <a href="Congress%20of%20Nuevo%20Le%C3%B3n">Congress of Nuevo León</a>, and has served in the <a href="Chamber%20of%20Deputies%20of%20Mexico">Chamber of Deputies of Mexico</a> during the LVI and <a href="LIX%20Legislature%20of%20the%20Mexican%20Congress">LIX Legislature</a>. In 2006 she was elected to serve as municipal president (mayor) of the municipality of <a href="Guadalupe%20%28Nuevo%20Le%C3%B3n%29">Guadalupe</a>.
Duties in the Institutional Revolutionary Party.
She was the secretary general of the PRI, until December 2, 2011. After the resignation of <a href="Humberto%20Moreira">Humberto Moreira</a> as <a href="President%20of%20the%20Institutional%20Revolutionary%20Party">President of the Institutional Revolutionary Party</a>, she became the interim president of the party; but when <a href="Pedro%20Joaqu%C3%ADn%20Coldwell">Pedro Joaquín Coldwell</a> took office as president of the party, she became the secretary general of the party again on December 8, 2011.
